A summary of this week

Mathematics and programming

A big discussion this week was about usability versus the readability of code. Last week I implemented the Kalman filter equations in Jax. To do this, I tried to keep the code as close to the math as possible. For example, the initial conditions of the Kalman filter can be written as follows:

K1=Σ0+CT(CΣ0CT+R)μ1=μ0+K1(x0−Cμ0)Σ1=(I−K1C)Σ0\begin{aligned} {\bf K}_1 &= \bold{\Sigma}_0 + {\bf C}^T \left({\bf C} \bold{\Sigma}_0 {\bf C}^T + {\bf R}\right)\\ {\boldsymbol \mu}_1 &= {\boldsymbol \mu_0} + {\bf K}_1 ({\bf x}_0 - {\bf C} {\boldsymbol \mu}_0)\\ \bold{\Sigma}_1 &= ({\bf I} - {\bf K}_1 {\bf C}) \bold{\Sigma}_0\end{aligned}K1​μ1​Σ1​​=Σ0​+CT(CΣ0​CT+R)=μ0​+K1​(x0​−Cμ0​)=(I−K1​C)Σ0​​

To implement this set of equations in Jax, I wrote the following code

K1 = self.Σ0 @ self.C.T @ inv(self.C @ self.Σ0 @ self.C.T + self.R)μ1 = self.μ0 + K1 @ (x_hist[0] - self.C @ self.μ0)Σ1 = (I - K1 @ self.C) @ self.Σ0

One problem with the previous code, however, is the hardship to explicitly initialize the class due to the presence of the Greek symbols. To solve this, it was proposed to write Sigma instead of Σ, and mu instead of μ. The resulting code was the following:

K1 = self.Sigma0 @ self.C.T @ inv(self.C @ self.Sigma0 @ self.C.T + self.R)mu1 = self.mu0 + K1 @ (x_hist[0] - self.C @ self.mu0)Sigma1 = (I - K1 @ self.C) @ self.Sigma0

Although the final code did not look ugly, this issue made think of the code we write and context it surrounds it. If a code tries to teach rather than be used in production, I believe it is fair to use greek symbols. It would be painful to use scikit-learn and initialize a variable α in multiple models. However, if I’m looking to directly translate some math concept that I’ve already understood into code, the easiest way to do this is to write code as close as possible to the math.

File

  • linear_dynamical_systems_lib.py

Parallel and Spiral Kalman Filters

A second refactoring task this week was to clean the parallel_kalman_filter_demo.py and making sure that it works using the class LinearDynamicalSystem inside the linear_dynamical_systems_lib.py without break the previously-implemented kalman_tracking_demo.py. It wasn’t the most exciting task of the week, but in the end I got a pretty refactored graph of tracking multiple fireworks at once.

A final Kalman filter task this week was to clean and upload the kalman_filter_spiral_demo.py of a system with imaginary eigenvalues. Although I got some pretty results last week, this week I made sure that the code was pretty and worked.

Files

  • parallel_kalman_filter_demo.py
  • kalman_filter_spiral_demo.py

Extended Kalman Filtering (EKF)

After multiple days of refactoring, I got to play with my favourite example this week. The idea is fairly simple (although to really understand what is going on, it’s better to read PML Vol 2 book). The classical Kalman filter equations only work when both the latent and the observed space are linear. If either the observed space or the latent-space do not emerge from a linear system, the Kalman filter equations cannot capture the latent space from the observed data. The idea behind the EKF is to make a first-order approximation to capture the latent behaviour of a nonlinear dynamical system. To exemplify this, I proposed we used the following nonlinear dynamical system with identity observed function:

x˙=yy˙=x−x3\begin{aligned} \dot x &= y\\ \dot y &= x - x ^ 3\end{aligned}x˙y˙​​=y=x−x3​

The interesting bit in this example is to realize that the dynamics to capture are comprised of a set of differential equations. Furthermore, when tracking an object using EKF we may not observe every single sample. Hence, we first simulated the latent state space; then we added some noise to obtain the observations; finally, we divided the observations into evenly-spaced intervals and tried to recapture the latent space. What resulted was an interesting example where, in order to recover the latent dataset, we used Runge-Kutta to integrate between two observed samples.

Files

  • extended_kalman_filter_demo.py

Variational Mixture of Gaussian distributions

The final example I worked on this week was the variational mixture of Gaussians example using TensorFlow Probability (TFP) and Jax. The goal was to show how the variational mixture of Gaussians with a pre-specified factorization and selection of prior distributions give rise to a model that finds clusters in the data and eliminates clusters that have low probability.

The following two figure shows the first and 100th iteration of the model. At the beginning we pre-specified 6 clusters. Each cluster tries to find a group of points to bound to. As the iterations progress, if there is not enough data to support one cluster, that cluster gets eliminated.

In the next picture, we show the number of points attach to a cluster. As the iterations progresses, we see how all but two clusters remain “alive”.

This week marked the end of week 0 of the 2021 Google Summer of Code (GSoC). This year, I got accepted to work on the “Converting ML Matlab Examples to Python using JAX” under the Tensorflow organization. The goal of the project is to translate machine learning Matlab code to Python/Jax for Kevin Murphy’s second volume of his upcoming book “Probabilistic Machine Learning: Advanced Topics”.

According to GSoC’s calendar, the first two weeks of GSoC are for “community bonding”. In fact, it is written that

[the students, if accepted] spend a few weeks integrating with their organizations prior to the start of coding. Students then have 10 weeks to code, meeting the deadlines agreed upon with their mentors.

It turns out that for the project I’m working on, the first two weeks of community bonding have been full of communication and lots of code. Our mentors, Kevin Murphy and Mahmoud Soliman have made of the first two weeks challenging but rewarding.

In what follows, I will give a brief overview of the things I learned, PRs I made, and graphs I plotted during my first two weeks.

A summary of the past two weeks

Kalman Filters

One of the main challenges these past two weeks has been the creation of a small Kalman Filter library that uses Jax. In this demo, we used Jax to simulate a firework that moves at varying speed. We then compare the estimated trajectory given by the Kalman Filter equations v.s. the Kalman Smoothing equations.

At the beginning I wasn’t too sure why it was decided to use Jax given that we require for-loops to compute the Kalman Filters. However, it all pay off once we used Jax’s vmap for an impressive increase in speedup (see last subsection for more information).

Files

  • scripts/kalman_tracking_demo.py
  • scripts/linear_dynamical_systems.py

MCMC Sampling

Although most of the issues/figures to work on were assigned to us. I decided to self-assign the MCMC demo to me.

The plots above perfectly portray what is really happening in Gibbs and Metropolis-Hastings sampling. It’s a clear representation that these two methods of MCMC sampling return autocorrelated samples, which may be undesirable if we want to simulate an i.i.d. process. Furthermore, we can see the effect of the step-size in a run of the HM sampling algorithm.

Files

  • scripts/mcmc_gmm_demo.py

Occasionally Dishonest Casino

This has been one of my favourite examples so far. In an occasionally dishonest casino, we assume that every time we throw a die, there is a certain probability that the die will either be biased –in which case, the probability of landing a 6 is 5/10 and all other numbers 1/10–, or be unbiased, i.e., every number has an equal 1/6 probability. The goal was to use a Hidden Markov Model (HMM) to recover the times in which the die was biased given that we only have the history of the numbers that appeared under the throw of a dice:

x: 666333434452361543336162146653316146656663144434652652444446z: 222222221111111111111111111111111112222222222222222211111111

The first plot (above) is the equivalent of the Kalman-Filter equation of a Hidden Markov Model. It tries to recover in real time whether a certain observation, conditional on previous observations, belongs to the biased state or the unbiased state. The second figure is the smoothing part that allows us to retroactively analyze whether any given throw is biased or unbiased. Finally, the last plot shows the most likely path using the Viterbi algorithm.

Files

  • scripts/hmm_casino_demo.py
  • scripts/hmm_lib.py

More Kalman Filtering: Fireworks

The highlight of week zero for me came with Kevin’s proposal that we use Jax’s vmap function to speedup the Kalman Filter demo that I previously wrote. The goal was to run the Kalman Filter for 20 “fireworks” simultaneously. I was impressed to see that the speedup was around 80% using vmap on a Google Colab 2-core machine than using a for loop over simulations. The following was the result:

%%timekey = random.PRNGKey(27182)for n in range(n_samples):  lds_instance = lds.LinearDynamicalSystem(A, C, Q, R, μ0, Σ0, n_steps)  result = sample_filter_smooth(key, lds_instance)> CPU times: user 10.8 s, sys: 1.18 s, total: 12 s> Wall time: 9.93 s
%%timekey = random.PRNGKey(27182)lds_instance = lds.ParallelLinearDynamicalSystem(A, C, Q, R, μ0, Σ0, n_steps)result = sample_filter_smooth(key, lds_instance, n_samples, True)> CPU times: user 1.49 s, sys: 70.4 ms, total: 1.57 s> Wall time: 1.44 s

Files

  • scripts/linear_dynamical_systems.py (vmap version currently under review)
  • parallel_kalman_filter.py (Currently under review)

More Kalman Filtering: Imaginary-Eigenvalue systems

One final application of the Kalman Filters that I worked on these past week consists in modelling a linear dynamical system with imaginary eigenvalues. Even though the observations may seem to stem from a nonlinear system, the system stills follows a linear evolution over time, it follows that the Kalman Filter should work, and so it does!

items.title: The Student's t-Distribution: A financial approach
items.content_html:
Introduction

Picture your favourite stock. Regardless of its average performance, its price has experienced ups and downs that are due to external factors such as pandemics, financial crises, bad publicity, or press leaks. If we only know the price of the stock, we do not know which factor caused which movements in the price of your stock.

Considering the above, how can we model the distribution of returns? One solution would be to assume that both the volatility of the stock and the average rate of return are constant and model the returns as a Normal distribution. The problem with this approach is that big movements in the price of the stock may not be explained by our constant volatility and may be deemed as outliers by our model.

Consider, for example, the daily (linear) returns of TSLA between June 30, 2010 and September 16, 2020. The following graph shows the histogram of historical returns for TSLA, as well as its adjusted normal distribution.

As we can see from the graph above, a Normal distribution is unable to take into account the fluctuation of the stock: less probability is assigned around the mean, and more probability at the tails. Consequently, what we believe to be outlier events may happen more frequently than we would expect and ordinary events less frequently.

To work around this drawback, let us assume that the return of the stock at time ttt is Normally-distributed with constant average rate of return, and a volatility that depends on ttt. Modelling the rate of return in this particular way will leads us to the famous distribution known as the Student’s-t distribution. In effect, we want to model the rate of return not as a single normal distribution, but rather as a collection of Normal distributions.

The data generating process

Let StS_tSt​ be the price of the stock at time ttt; let rtr_trt​ be the arithmetic change of the stock at time ttt, that is rt=St−St−1r_t = S_{t} - S_{t-1}rt​=St​−St−1​. On a given day ttt, an event EtE_tEt​ occurs. EtE_tEt​ has a direct impact on the rate of return of our stock rtr_trt​ by either increasing or decreasing its volatility.1 The greater the volatility, the greater values rtr_trt​ can take on a particular ttt.

More specifically, let us assume that the return for the stock on a given day is normally-distributed with mean μ\muμ and variance σt2\sigma_t^2σt2​ (notice the dependence of σt2\sigma^2_tσt2​ on the time). That is,

rt∼N(μ,σt2) r_t \sim \mathcal{N}(\mu, \sigma_t^2)rt​∼N(μ,σt2​)

Since we cannot observe EtE_tEt​ directly (we only know that it exists), we capture the effect that any EtE_tEt​ has over σt2\sigma^2_tσt2​ using a probability distribution. To put it in other words, the return of the stock is driven by two forces: the first force determines the uncertainty at time ttt (the volatility), and the second force, which depends on the first force, determines the actual return at time ttt, namely, rtr_trt​. Statistically, this process can be seen as a procedure with two steps

  1. First, sample σt2\sigma^2_tσt2​ from a given distribution p(σt2)p(\sigma^2_t)p(σt2​); next
  2. sample rtr_trt​ from a distribution N(rt∣μ,σt2)\mathcal{N}(r_t \vert \mu, \sigma^2_t)N(rt​∣μ,σt2​)

The following picture shows this idea. At each time-step ttt, a value σt2\sigma^2_tσt2​ is generated (the orange bars). This generated value is then used to sample from N(μ,σt2)\mathcal{N}(\mu, \sigma^2_t)N(μ,σt2​). As we can see, days of high volatility, are correlated with days of higher change in the price StS_tSt​.

Under these assumptions, there not a σ2\sigma_2σ2​ but a whole distribution of them. Alternatively: the volatility is also a random variable: clearly there is no point modelling rtr_trt​ as a normal distribution unless we know σt2\sigma^2_tσt2​ at every ttt.

What’s your expectation?

At this point, we might think that we are in a little bit of a trouble to model rtr_trt​. Thankfully for us, the Head Brewer for the Guiness company, a man named William Sealy Gosset, published a paper under the pseudonym “Student” solving this exact problem (of course, he was interested in measurements of beer and not about your favourite stock).

Instead of modelling rtr_trt​ at every ttt, why don’t we get rid of the term that depends on ttt? If we assume that the probability distribution p(σt2)p(\sigma^2_t)p(σt2​) is the same for all ttt, then we can find a time-independent distribution p(r)p(r)p(r) by averaging-out all possible values of σt2\sigma^2_tσt2​.

More concretely, the average rate of return rrr is distributed according to a probability density function (pdf) given by

p(r)=∫0∞N(r∣μ,σ2)p(σ2)dσ2=Eσ2[N(r∣μ,σ2)]\begin{aligned}p(r) &=\int_0^\infty \mathcal{N}(r\vert\mu, \sigma^2 ) p(\sigma^2) d\sigma^2\\&=\mathbb{E}_{\sigma^2}[\mathcal{N}(r\vert\mu, \sigma^2 )]\end{aligned}p(r)​=∫0∞​N(r∣μ,σ2)p(σ2)dσ2=Eσ2​[N(r∣μ,σ2)]​

The following graph represents this marginalisation.

To solve this integral, we need to assign a probability density function (pdf) to p(σ2)p(\sigma^2)p(σ2). Since σt2\sigma^2_tσt2​ takes values in the set R+∪{0}\mathbb{R}^+ \cup \{0\}R+∪{0}, a good candidate for this distribution is the Gamma(α,β)\text{Gamma}(\alpha, \beta)Gamma(α,β) distribution given by

Gamma(x∣α,β)=βαΓ(α)xα−1exp⁡(−βx) \text{Gamma}(x\vert\alpha, \beta) = \frac{\beta^\alpha}{\Gamma(\alpha)} x^{\alpha-1}\exp(-\beta x)Gamma(x∣α,β)=Γ(α)βα​xα−1exp(−βx)

However, in order to have a tractable integral, we denote τ=1/σ2\tau = 1 / \sigma^2τ=1/σ2 as the precision of a Normal distribution and model the time-independent distribution as

p(r)=∫0∞N(r∣μ,τ)Gam(τ∣α,β)dτp(r) = \int_0^{\infty} \mathcal{N}(r\vert\mu, \tau ) \text{Gam}(\tau\vert \alpha, \beta ) d\taup(r)=∫0∞​N(r∣μ,τ)Gam(τ∣α,β)dτ

The analytical solution to this integral gives rise to the t-distribution given by

p(r)=Γ(ν/2+1/2)Γ(ν/2)2π(2λν)1/2(λ(r−μ)2ν+1)−ν12−12p(r) = \frac{\Gamma(\nu/2 + 1/2)}{\Gamma(\nu/2)\sqrt{2\pi}}\left(\frac{2\lambda}{\nu}\right)^{1/2}\left(\frac{\lambda(r-\mu)^2}{\nu} +1\right)^{-\nu\frac{1}{2} - \frac{1}{2}}p(r)=Γ(ν/2)2π​Γ(ν/2+1/2)​(ν2λ​)1/2(νλ(r−μ)2​+1)−ν21​−21​

With ν=2α\nu = 2\alphaν=2α, λ=α/β\lambda=\alpha/\betaλ=α/β.

Fitting the data

Coming back to our initial problem, how well does a student distribution models the return of our stockrrr? In the following graph we show the result of of fitting the returns of TSLA to a t-distribution. In comparison to a Normal distribution, we can see that fitting a t-distribution can more accurately represent the returns of the stock.

Appendix: Deriving the Student’s-t distribution

items.content_html:
On July 10, 2018 I committed myself to read and do all the exercises of the book Pattern Recognition and Machine Learning from Christopher Bishop. After seven hundred and ninety two days, I can finally say I accomplished my goal.

One of the main reasons why I decided to study the book from cover to cover was to demystify machine learning (ML). Reading through the book taught me to question the underlying assumptions behind every model, to understand from a mathematical point of view why some models fail, and to not fret the mathematics behind ML. Most importantly, I understood why ML is hard, to be humbled by it and to not take models as recipes that we can use as we please.

Whilst studying the book, I had a small side project that consisted in clocking every time I opened the book using the Toggl application. The goal of this blog post, therefore, is not to discuss the intricate chapters of the book, but rather to tell a story with data on how I managed to finish the book, my experiences and what data can tell me about my own patterns.

Part1: Temporal Analysis

Daily Hours

I started studying PRML on July 10, 2018 at 17:21pm. The first time I opened the book I did not know that I was going to read it from cover to cover. In fact, it was not until one month later, on august 27, 2018, the day of my birthday, that I decided to pursue a thorough study of the book. I do not recall much of that day, other than, according to my notes, I studied for 18 minutes. Interestingly though, my following two birthdays saw a rise the in the number of hours that I clocked:

Birthday year clocked hours
2018 0.3
2019 1.25
2020 2.43

Around that time, I decided to study for two hours every single day until the day I finished the book. Considering the 792 days that took me to study the book from cover to cover, I should’ve gotten 1,584 hours worth of study, but instead, I got 1,542.72 hours. A close 97% of my goal.

The following graph shows the total number of clocked hours (top plot) and my deficit of hours (bottom plot), i.e., the difference between the number of hours that I should’ve studied v.s. the actual number of hours that I studied.

An interesting observation from the graph above is to note the total number of days in which I did not clock a single hour of study is 48. Before starting doing this analysis I could’ve sworn that I had less than 5 days in which I did not study!

Another interesting observation from the previous graph is that I was on a time-deficit of almost 150 hours pre-covid19. But during the pandemic I managed to recover more than 100 hours worth of study, which led me to finish the book with a 43-hour deficit; or almost 21 days worth of study.

Without consideration of the days in which I did not clock my studies, I get an average study time of 2.17 hours per day. If I do consider them, I get an average of around 1.94 hours of study per day which, of course, is the 97% of 2.

The following graphs shows the distribution of hours of study per day without taking into account the 48 days in which I did not clock my studies. It shows that, on an average day, I would’ve studied between 1.4 and 3 hours.

Time of study

My decision to study two hours per day stemmed from the fact that I was working full-time on my startup. Even though I had more freedom to choose when I decided to start studying, I was constraint to my deadlines, meetings with clients, other models I was working on, etc. This, not only restricted how much could I study in one day, but also when did I start studying. In this section, I discuss my patterns in regards of my times of study.

The following histogram represents the distribution of times that I started clocking a study session. As we can see, it is centered at around 10 am, but it has a significant standard deviation of 4 hours. Meaning that roughly, on a normal day, I could’ve been studying anywhere from 6am to 2pm. Of course, these statistics do not truly represent what would happen on a normal day since the distribution seems to be right skewed and possibly multimodal.

In order to better understand my patterns of study we can consider the distribution of times that I started studying, grouped by weekday represented in the graph below. Clearly, Monday through Friday seem to be the days whose distributions look closest. Saturdays and Sundays however, diverge from the rest. Saturday, on the one hand, seems to have a mean that is closer to the early hours of the morning, while on the other hand, Sunday seems to be the weekday with higher probability of study in later hours of the day.

An additional way to distill how much time I dedicated myself to study is to consider the following heatmap which represents the total number of hours that I studied, grouped by day of the week and the rounded hour in which I started studying.

It came as a surprise to learn that my favorite day and hour of study was on Saturdays at 6am. In other timeframe did I get above 50 hours worth of study. Conversely, all workweek days seem pretty standard and not deviate much from the norm. On Sundays had the highest probability of studying after 9am. Finally, as with every dataset, there must be some outlier datapoints. In my case, it was the hours of study in very early in the morning, particularly on Thursdays.

Part 2: Chapter Analysis

As it is with any other topic in mathematics, not al subjects in a book have the same difficulty. One rough estimation on how hard each chapter was for me is to consider the amount of hours that I spent on that chapter.

Chapter 1: Introduction                        128.755833Chapter 2: Probability distributions           208.143611Chapter 3: Linear Models for Regression        105.791389Chapter 4: Linear Models for Classification    102.149167Chapter 5: Neural Networks                     200.052120Chapter 6: Kernel Methods                       61.676944Chapter 7: Sparse Kernel Machines               79.763056Chapter 8: Graphical Models                     96.968333Chapter 9: Mixture Models and EM                79.607500Chapter 10: Approximate Inference              226.593056Chapter 11: Sampling Methods                    27.502500Chapter 12: Continuous Latent Variables         91.390833Chapter 13: Sequential Data                    104.260833Chapter 14: Combining Models                    30.071667Name: study-hours, dtype: float64

Before starting my analysis, I had the hypothesis that harder chapters must, of course, take longer to complete. What I did not consider, however, was the length of each chapter (which is easy to measure), the amount of hours that I dedicated myself to a particular exercise in the chapter (which I did not measure), and finally the depth of each chapter (which is hard to measure). Chapter 2, for example, was about topic I was already familiar with, namely, probability distributions. But despite this fact, it was the second chapter with most clocked hours. I did not feel that the chapter was particularly difficult, but the way in which the author talked about the subject made pay particularly attention to the details.

The following graph corrects for the number of pages in each chapter by dividing the total number of hours spent per chapter by the total number of pages in that chapter.

Looking at the graph tells a slightly different story, but not the complete one. Chapter 14, for instance, was a high-pace chapter since it involved many concepts that were presented in earlier parts of the book, which made the reading easy to do and the exercises relatively easy to complete.

To finalize with this analysis, I can combined the previous two analyses to get to my final graph: the time spent on each chapter as a function of the date that I started studying it. The y-axis represents the total number of hours clocked per week, and the x-axis represents the end of each week.

Looking at this graphs makes me quickly forget that the datapoints represent me. Between every two dashed lines in the graph there was a Gerardo experiencing something: a great weekend at the beach, a rough day at work, a day of worries or happiness. It sometimes easy to forget that as we work with data about people, there are stories that we are not taking account for. Latent variables that could better explain our patterns of behavior.

Conclusion

The book Pattern Recognition and Machine Learning became my day-to-day life for more than two years. Looking back at my experiences with the book in the form of data is, to me, the only reasonable way to make an homage to such an inspiring book.

Furthermore, the analyses of my patterns in the form of hard data can help me overcome my next big goal. There are many things I would’ve done differently such as being more rigorous on how my data was extracted or write in words how I feeling on a particular day. But the key lesson that I learned from this experience is that consistency can take me anywhere.

Uncertainty in the markets can be represented as a function of price fluctuation. The greater the price of an asset can change between any two periods of time, the less certain one can be about the future value of that asset.

The statistical measure of price fluctuation of an asset is known as volatility.

Volatility is therefore of the utmost importance in financial risk management in calculations such as the “Value at Risk” (VaR) which estimates how much a set of investments might lose (with a given probability)1.

The aim of this post is to introduce to two classical volatility forecasting models and understand how can we make use of machine learning to derive an alternative model for volatility forecasting.

GARCH(1,1)

A Generalized AutoRegressive Conditional Heteroskedasticity (GARCH) model assumes that an asset SSS is has a constant rate of return μ\muμ and a volatility σt2\sigma^2_tσt2​ that depends on the volatility and the return of the asset at time t−1t-1t−1 plus a constant term.

class GARCHSigmas:    """    Class to estimate the sigma_t values    of a GARCH(1, 1)    """    def __init__(self, omega, alpha, beta, sigma_init, R):        self.omega = omega        self.alpha = alpha        self.beta = beta````        self.R = R        self.sigma_hist = [sigma_init]        self.initialize_sigmas()        def get_sigma1(self, t):        rt0 = 0 if t == 0 else self.R.iloc[t - 1, 0]        sigma0 = self.sigma_hist[-1]        sigma1 = self.omega + self.alpha * rt0 ** 2 + self.beta * sigma0        self.sigma_hist.append(sigma1)        def initialize_sigmas(self):        N, M = self.R.shape        for t in range(N - 1, -1, -1):            self.get_sigma1(t)

The Glosten-Jagannathan-Runkle GARCH (GJR-GARCH) model is an alternative to a GARCH(1, 1) which considers an additional factor γ\gammaγ that models the assymetric response of the market to the sign of the return.

Introducción

y^(x)=w0+w1x+w2x2+w3x3=wTϕ(x)\begin{aligned} \hat y(x) &= w_0 + w_1 x + w_2 x^2 + w_3 x^3\\ &= {\bold w}^T\phi(\bold x)\end{aligned}y^​(x)​=w0​+w1​x+w2​x2+w3​x3=wTϕ(x)​

con w∈R3,x∈R\bold w\in \mathbb{R}^3, \bold x\in\mathbb{R}w∈R3,x∈R y ϕ(x)=(1,x,x2,x3)T\phi(x) = (1, x, x^2, x^3)^Tϕ(x)=(1,x,x2,x3)T.

Denotamos las observaciones en este ejemplo como una base de datos de la forma D={(xn,tn)∣xn∈R,tn∈R}n=1N\mathcal D=\{(x_n, t_n) | x_n\in\mathbb{R}, t_n\in\mathbb{R}\}_{n=1}^ND={(xn​,tn​)∣xn​∈R,tn​∈R}n=1N​. En este sentido,

Φ=[ϕ(x1)T⋮ϕ(xN)T] \boldsymbol\Phi = \begin{bmatrix} \rule{2.5ex}{0.5pt} & \phi(x_1)^T & \rule{2.5ex}{0.5pt} \\ & \vdots & \\ \rule{2.5ex}{0.5pt} & \phi(x_N)^T & \rule{2.5ex}{0.5pt} \\ \end{bmatrix}Φ=⎣⎢⎢⎡​​ϕ(x1​)T⋮ϕ(xN​)T​​⎦⎥⎥⎤​

Dado que asumimos una relación entre los datos dada por y^\hat yy^​, el resultado de esta relación depende únicamente del vector w\bold ww. Por otro lado, maximizar la distribución a posteriori p(w∣D)∝p(w)p(t∣x,w)p(\bold w | \mathcal D) \propto p(\bold w)p(\bold t|\bold x,\bold w)p(w∣D)∝p(w)p(t∣x,w) respecto a w\bold ww asumiendo que p(w)=N(w∣0,α−1I)p(\bold w) = \mathcal{N}(\bold w | \bold 0, \alpha^{-1}\bold I)p(w)=N(w∣0,α−1I) es equivalente a ajustar un modelo Lasso con parámetro λ=βα\lambda = \frac{\beta}{\alpha}λ=αβ​.

Una tercera manera de analizar esta bondad de ajuste sería calculando la incertidumbre que tiene el modelo sobre los parámetros ajustados.

Esto es equivalente a encontrar la moda de p(w∣D)p(\bold w | \mathcal D)p(w∣D). Calcular únicamente la moda nos priva de cuestionar al modelo sobre varios estadísticos que podrían ser de interés. Con el fin de obtener una distribución de probabilidad, retomemos la forma de la distribución a posteriori de los parámetros dado por

p(w∣D)∝p(w)p(D∣w) p(\bold{w}|\mathcal{D}) \propto p(\bold{w})p(\mathcal{D}|\bold{w})p(w∣D)∝p(w)p(D∣w)

Subsecuentemente vemos que para la distribución a posteriori se cumple:

En la imagen se podían observar tres factores: puntos muestrales, la curva sobre la cual los puntos fueron generados y distribuciones Gaussianas sobre intervalos de la curva. La finalidad de la gráfica era ilustrar que la estimación de la regresión lineal dada una observación es igual a la esperanza condicional de la distribución de la variable que se espera modelar dada una observación.La conclusión de aquel capítulo era demostrar que un modelo de regresión lineal es de gran ayuda si la distribución condicional de nuestros datos se comporta normal y presenta homocedasticidad (varianza constante); pero, ¿qué sucede si esto no se cumple? Nuestra distribución podría tener varianza no constante o ni siquiera distribuirse Normal. De igual manera, ¿qué hacemos si no es de nuestro interés conocer una esperanza?Para motivar estas preguntas, consideremos el ejemplo de estar modelando el rendimiento de una acción para hacer un trade. Supongamos que x\bold xx es un vector que, asumimos, impacta al rendimiento ttt. De ajustar una regresión lineal sobre ttt considerando x\bold xx, al hacer una predicción sobre x\bold xx, el modelo únicamente nos proporcionaría E[t∣x]\mathbb{E}[t|\bold x]E[t∣x]. Si E[t∣x]>0\mathbb{E}[t|\bold x] > 0E[t∣x]>0, podríamos asumir que el trade tiene una esperanza de ser rentable, es decir, después de ejecutar una infinidad de veces la estrategia, esperaríamos tener un retorno positivo.Lamentablemente en el día a día no contamos con infinitas oportunidades para obtener un retorno positivo, por lo que deberíamos adoptar ciertas medidas de riesgo para la posición que queremos tomar. Si y(w,x)=wTxy(\bold w, \bold x) = \bold w^T \bold xy(w,x)=wTx, vemos que minimizar el negativo de la log-verosimilitud es encontrar wML\bold w_{ML}wML​ que minimize el error cuadrático, es decir, una regresión lineal.

Máximo a-Posteriori (MAP)

¿Qué sucede si la suposición de una verosimilitud muy puntiaguda no se cumple o existen variables dentro de nuestro modelo que son redundantes? Consideremos nuevamente la distribución a posteriori de nuestro modelo:

p(w∣D)∝p(w)p(D∣w) p(\bold{w}|\mathcal{D}) \propto p(\bold{w})p(\mathcal{D}|\bold{w})p(w∣D)∝p(w)p(D∣w)

Podemos introducir una creencia a-priori de que todos los pesos wi\bold w_iwi​ se centran al rededor del 000 como una distribución N(0,α−1I)\mathcal N(\bold 0, \alpha^{-1} I)N(0,α−1I). En este caso, de existir suficiente evidencia en la verosimilitud de que un parámetro wi\bold w_iwi​ no es cero, actualizaríamos nuestras creencias. Con esto

Donde denotamos y=(y(w,x1),…,y(w,xN))T\bold y = \big(y(\bold w, \bold x_1), \ldots, y(\bold w, \bold x_N)\big)^Ty=(y(w,x1​),…,y(w,xN​))T, t=(t1,…,tN)\bold t = \big(t_1, \ldots, t_N\big)t=(t1​,…,tN​).

Definiendo λ=α/β\lambda = \alpha/\betaλ=α/β formulamos nuestro problema comowMAP=arg min⁡w∣∣t−y∣∣2+λ∣∣w∣∣2 \bold w_{\text{MAP}} = \argmin_{\bold w} ||\bold t - \bold y||^2 +\lambda ||\bold w||^2wMAP​=wargmin​∣∣t−y∣∣2+λ∣∣w∣∣2

Si y(w,x)=wTxy(\bold w, \bold x) = \bold w^T \bold xy(w,x)=wTx, encontrar wMAP\bold w_{\text{MAP}}wMAP​ se conoce como Ridge regression. En terminología de Machine Learning, el término ∣∣t−y∣∣2+λ∣∣w∣∣2||\bold t - \bold y||^2 +\lambda ||\bold w||^2∣∣t−y∣∣2+λ∣∣w∣∣2 es una función de costos; donde λ∣∣w∣∣2\lambda ||\bold w||^2λ∣∣w∣∣2 es conocido como el término de regularización.

En conclusión

Un modelo dado por máxima verosimilitud o máximo a posteriori es útil si el supuesto de distribución condicional a posteriori con mínima varianza se cumple. En la práctica esto último no siempre es verdad ya que se podrían tener poco datos, en cuyo caso esperaríamos que la distribución a posteriori tenga una gran varianza; o, de estar modelando seríes de tiempo, existir cambios estructurales, por lo que la cantidad de datos relevantes disminuiría.

En una segunda parte, analizaremos más a detalle las implicaciones de trabajar con un modelo totalmente probabilístico y poder medir la incertidumbre de nuestras estimaciones.
